title: Parameters and Return Values
objectives: Understand how to send information INTO functions using parameters
Learn how to get information OUT of functions using return values
Master the difference between parameters and arguments
Create flexible functions that work with different inputs

sections.title: The Concept
sections.content:
ğŸ° Functions: The Input-Process-Output Machine

Real-World Analogy First:

Imagine a smoothie blender at a juice bar:

  • ğŸ“ INPUT: You put in strawberries, banana, and yogurt
  • âš™ï¸ PROCESS: The blender mixes them together
  • ğŸ¥¤ OUTPUT: You get a delicious smoothie

The ingredients you put in are different each time (maybe today you want mango instead of strawberries), but the blender always does the same process. The result you get depends on what you put in!

This is exactly how function parameters and return values work:

  • ğŸ”µ Parameters are the INPUTS (ingredients)
  • ğŸ”µ Return values are the OUTPUTS (smoothie)
  • ğŸ”µ The function is the PROCESS (blending)

Now The Technical Terms:

Parameters: Variables in the function definition that receive input values. They're like empty containers waiting to be filled.

Arguments: The actual values you pass when calling the function. They're what fills those containers.

Return Value: The result that comes back from the function. Functions can send information back to the code that called them.

Why This Matters:

  • âœ… Flexibility: One function works with many different inputs
  • âœ… Reusability: Same function for different data
  • âœ… Communication: Functions can share results with other parts of your program
  • âœ… Testability: Give input, check output - easy to test!

sections.title: Code Example
sections.content:
ğŸ’» Functions With Parameters and Return Values

Let's create functions that accept inputs and produce outputs:
sections.code:
# Function WITH parameters (accepts inputs)
def greet_person(name):
    """Greet a specific person by name."""
    print(f"Hello, {name}! Welcome to Python functions!")

# Function WITH parameters AND return value
def calculate_area(length, width):
    """Calculate the area of a rectangle and return the result."""
    area = length * width
    return area  # Send the result back

# Function that returns a value directly
def double_number(num):
    """Return double the given number."""
    return num * 2

# Function with multiple return values
def get_name_parts(full_name):
    """Split a full name into first and last name."""
    parts = full_name.split()
    first = parts[0]
    last = parts[-1]
    return first, last  # Returns a tuple with two values


# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# USING THE FUNCTIONS
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

print("1ï¸âƒ£ Function with parameter (input):")
greet_person("Alice")  # "Alice" is the argument
greet_person("Bob")    # "Bob" is the argument
print()

print("2ï¸âƒ£ Function with parameters and return value:")
result = calculate_area(5, 3)  # Arguments: 5 and 3
print(f"Area of 5 x 3 rectangle: {result}")

result2 = calculate_area(10, 7)
print(f"Area of 10 x 7 rectangle: {result2}")
print()

print("3ï¸âƒ£ Using return value in expressions:")
doubled = double_number(7)
print(f"7 doubled is {doubled}")
print(f"20 doubled is {double_number(20)}")  # Use directly!
print()

print("4ï¸âƒ£ Multiple return values:")
first_name, last_name = get_name_parts("Alice Johnson")
print(f"First: {first_name}")
print(f"Last: {last_name}")
sections.output:
1ï¸âƒ£ Function with parameter (input):
Hello, Alice! Welcome to Python functions!
Hello, Bob! Welcome to Python functions!

2ï¸âƒ£ Function with parameters and return value:
Area of 5 x 3 rectangle: 15
Area of 10 x 7 rectangle: 70

3ï¸âƒ£ Using return value in expressions:
7 doubled is 14
20 doubled is 40

4ï¸âƒ£ Multiple return values:
First: Alice
Last: Johnson

sections.title: Syntax Breakdown
sections.content:
ğŸ” Understanding Parameters and Return

Part 1: Function Parameters (Inputs)

def greet_person(name):
    print(f"Hello, {name}!")
  • ğŸ“Œ name is a parameter - a variable that receives a value
  • ğŸ“Œ Parameters go inside the parentheses in the function definition
  • ğŸ“Œ You can have multiple parameters: def calculate_area(length, width):
  • ğŸ“Œ Parameters are separated by commas
  • ğŸ“Œ These are like empty boxes waiting to receive values

Part 2: Calling With Arguments

greet_person("Alice")  # "Alice" is an argument
  • ğŸ“Œ "Alice" is an argument - the actual value you pass
  • ğŸ“Œ When you call the function, the argument fills the parameter
  • ğŸ“Œ Inside the function, name becomes "Alice"
  • ğŸ“Œ Different call, different argument: greet_person("Bob") makes name become "Bob"

Memory Trick: Parameters are in the definition (both start with P-words: "Put" in definition). Arguments are when you call (both start with A-words: "Actual" values).

Part 3: The Return Statement

def calculate_area(length, width):
    area = length * width
    return area  # Send result back
  • ğŸ“Œ return keyword sends a value back to the caller
  • ğŸ“Œ The function immediately exits when it hits return
  • ğŸ“Œ The return value can be stored: result = calculate_area(5, 3)
  • ğŸ“Œ Or used directly: print(calculate_area(5, 3))

Part 4: Functions Without Return

def greet_person(name):
    print(f"Hello, {name}!")
    # No return statement
  • ğŸ“Œ If no return statement, the function returns None
  • ğŸ“Œ None is Python's way of saying "no value"
  • ğŸ“Œ These functions DO something (side effect) but don't give back a result

Part 5: Multiple Return Values

def get_name_parts(full_name):
    # ... processing ...
    return first, last  # Returns a tuple
  • ğŸ“Œ Separate values with commas: return first, last
  • ğŸ“Œ Python packs them into a tuple automatically
  • ğŸ“Œ Unpack when calling: first_name, last_name = get_name_parts("Alice Johnson")

Visual Model:

         CALLING CODE              FUNCTION
         â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

    result = calculate_area(5, 3)
                   â†“        â†“  â†“
                   â†“    length width
                   â†“        â†“  â†“
                   â†“    def calculate_area(length, width):
                   â†“        area = length * width
                   â†“        return area
                   â†“           â†“
                   â†“â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â†“ (returns 15)
                   â†“
               result = 15

âš ï¸ Common Confusion:

# âŒ WRONG - using print instead of return
def add(a, b):
    print(a + b)  # This displays but doesn't RETURN

result = add(5, 3)  # result is None, not 8!

# âœ… CORRECT - using return
def add(a, b):
    return a + b  # This returns the value

result = add(5, 3)  # result is 8

sections.title: Exercise
sections.content:
âœï¸ Your Turn: Temperature Converter

Challenge: Create a function that converts Celsius to Fahrenheit and returns the result.

Formula: fahrenheit = (celsius * 9/5) + 32

Requirements:

  1. Function name: celsius_to_fahrenheit
  2. One parameter: celsius (the temperature in Celsius)
  3. Calculate the Fahrenheit equivalent using the formula
  4. Return the result (don't just print it!)
  5. Include a docstring
  6. Test with at least 3 different temperatures

Example Usage:

temp_f = celsius_to_fahrenheit(0)
print(f"0Â°C = {temp_f}Â°F")  # Should print: 0Â°C = 32.0Â°F

temp_f = celsius_to_fahrenheit(100)
print(f"100Â°C = {temp_f}Â°F")  # Should print: 100Â°C = 212.0Â°F

Bonus Challenge: Create a second function fahrenheit_to_celsius that does the reverse conversion!

Formula: celsius = (fahrenheit - 32) * 5/9
sections.starter_code:
# Define your celsius_to_fahrenheit function
def celsius_to_fahrenheit(celsius):
    # Your docstring here
    
    # Calculate fahrenheit using the formula
    
    # Return the result
    pass  # Remove this when you add your code

# BONUS: Define fahrenheit_to_celsius function
def fahrenheit_to_celsius(fahrenheit):
    # Your code here
    pass

# Test your function with different values
# Your test code here

sections.title: Solution
sections.code:
# Main challenge: Celsius to Fahrenheit
def celsius_to_fahrenheit(celsius):
    """Convert temperature from Celsius to Fahrenheit.
    
    Args:
        celsius: Temperature in degrees Celsius
    
    Returns:
        Temperature in degrees Fahrenheit
    """
    fahrenheit = (celsius * 9/5) + 32
    return fahrenheit

# Bonus: Fahrenheit to Celsius
def fahrenheit_to_celsius(fahrenheit):
    """Convert temperature from Fahrenheit to Celsius.
    
    Args:
        fahrenheit: Temperature in degrees Fahrenheit
    
    Returns:
        Temperature in degrees Celsius
    """
    celsius = (fahrenheit - 32) * 5/9
    return celsius

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# TESTING THE FUNCTIONS
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

print("ğŸŒ¡ï¸  CELSIUS TO FAHRENHEIT")
print("â•" * 40)

# Test 1: Freezing point of water
temp_f = celsius_to_fahrenheit(0)
print(f"0Â°C = {temp_f}Â°F")

# Test 2: Boiling point of water
temp_f = celsius_to_fahrenheit(100)
print(f"100Â°C = {temp_f}Â°F")

# Test 3: Normal body temperature
temp_f = celsius_to_fahrenheit(37)
print(f"37Â°C = {temp_f}Â°F")

# Test 4: Nice spring day
temp_f = celsius_to_fahrenheit(20)
print(f"20Â°C = {temp_f}Â°F")

print("\nğŸŒ¡ï¸  FAHRENHEIT TO CELSIUS (BONUS)")
print("â•" * 40)

# Reverse conversions
temp_c = fahrenheit_to_celsius(32)
print(f"32Â°F = {temp_c}Â°C")

temp_c = fahrenheit_to_celsius(212)
print(f"212Â°F = {temp_c}Â°C")

temp_c = fahrenheit_to_celsius(98.6)
print(f"98.6Â°F = {temp_c}Â°C")

print("\nğŸ”„ ROUND TRIP TEST (Should get back original):")
print("â•" * 40)
original = 25
to_f = celsius_to_fahrenheit(original)
back_to_c = fahrenheit_to_celsius(to_f)
print(f"{original}Â°C â†’ {to_f}Â°F â†’ {back_to_c}Â°C")
print(f"Match: {abs(original - back_to_c) < 0.0001}")  # Check if equal
sections.output:
ğŸŒ¡ï¸  CELSIUS TO FAHRENHEIT
â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
0Â°C = 32.0Â°F
100Â°C = 212.0Â°F
37Â°C = 98.6Â°F
20Â°C = 68.0Â°F

ğŸŒ¡ï¸  FAHRENHEIT TO CELSIUS (BONUS)
â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
32Â°F = 0.0Â°C
212Â°F = 100.0Â°C
98.6Â°F = 37.0Â°C

ğŸ”„ ROUND TRIP TEST (Should get back original):
â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
25Â°C â†’ 77.0Â°F â†’ 25.0Â°C
Match: True
sections.explanation:
ğŸ“š How It Works:

  1. Function Structure (Lines 1-11):
    • def celsius_to_fahrenheit(celsius): defines function with ONE parameter
    • The parameter celsius receives whatever value we pass
    • Line 10: We calculate using the formula
    • Line 11: We return the result (not print!)
    • Extended docstring explains parameters and return value
  2. The Return Statement:
    • When we call celsius_to_fahrenheit(0), the function calculates (0 * 9/5) + 32 = 32.0
    • The return statement sends 32.0 back
    • We can store it: temp_f = celsius_to_fahrenheit(0)
    • Or use directly: print(celsius_to_fahrenheit(0))
  3. Bonus Function (Lines 13-23):
    • Same structure, different formula
    • Shows how functions can be inverses of each other
  4. Testing (Lines 25-57):
    • Test with known values (0Â°C = 32Â°F, 100Â°C = 212Â°F)
    • Use the return values in f-strings
    • Round-trip test: convert Câ†’Fâ†’C to verify accuracy

âš ï¸ Common Mistakes:

  1. Using print() Instead of return:
    # âŒ WRONG - prints but doesn't return
def celsius_to_fahrenheit(celsius):
    fahrenheit = (celsius * 9/5) + 32
    print(fahrenheit)  # Can't store or use this!

result = celsius_to_fahrenheit(0)  # result is None!

# âœ… CORRECT - returns the value
def celsius_to_fahrenheit(celsius):
    fahrenheit = (celsius * 9/5) + 32
    return fahrenheit  # Can store and use this
  2. Forgetting to Return:
    # âŒ WRONG - calculates but doesn't return
def celsius_to_fahrenheit(celsius):
    fahrenheit = (celsius * 9/5) + 32
    # Forgot return statement!

result = celsius_to_fahrenheit(0)  # result is None!
  3. Wrong Number of Arguments:
    # âŒ WRONG - function expects 1 argument
celsius_to_fahrenheit()  # TypeError: missing required argument
celsius_to_fahrenheit(0, 32)  # TypeError: too many arguments

# âœ… CORRECT - exactly 1 argument
celsius_to_fahrenheit(0)
  4. Not Using the Return Value:
    # âŒ WASTEFUL - function returns value but we ignore it
celsius_to_fahrenheit(100)  # Calculates but result is lost

# âœ… CORRECT - store or use the return value
temp = celsius_to_fahrenheit(100)
print(f"Temperature: {celsius_to_fahrenheit(100)}Â°F")
  5. Variable Name Confusion:
    # âŒ CONFUSING - reusing parameter name
celsius = 100
celsius = celsius_to_fahrenheit(celsius)  # Works but confusing

# âœ… CLEAR - different names for input and output
celsius = 100
fahrenheit = celsius_to_fahrenheit(celsius)

ğŸ’¡ Pro Tips:

  • âœ… Return, don't print: Functions should return values so other code can use them
  • âœ… Test with known values: 0Â°C = 32Â°F, 100Â°C = 212Â°F are easy to verify
  • âœ… Descriptive names: celsius_to_fahrenheit clearly shows what it does
  • âœ… Document parameters: Use docstrings to explain what inputs are expected
  • âœ… One calculation per function: Each function does one clear task

sections.title: Key Takeaways
sections.content:
ğŸ¯ Essential Points to Remember:

  1. Parameters vs Arguments:
    • Parameters: Variables in the function definition (def greet(name):)
    • Arguments: Actual values when calling (greet("Alice"))
    • Think: Parameters are empty boxes, arguments fill them
  2. Functions can accept inputs:
    def function_name(parameter1, parameter2):
    # Use the parameters inside
    • Parameters make functions flexible and reusable
    • Same function works with different data
  3. The return statement sends values back:
    def calculate(x):
    result = x * 2
    return result  # Send back to caller
    • Use return to give results back to the calling code
    • The function exits immediately when hitting return
  4. Return vs Print:
    • print() displays to screen (side effect, no value back)
    • return sends value back to the code (can be stored/used)
    • Functions should usually return values, not print them
  5. No return statement = returns None:
    • Functions without return automatically return None
    • These functions DO something (side effect) but don't provide a result
  6. Multiple return values:
    return value1, value2, value3  # Returns tuple
    • Separate with commas to return multiple values
    • Unpack when receiving: a, b, c = function()
  7. Using return values:
    result = calculate_area(5, 3)  # Store it
print(calculate_area(5, 3))     # Use directly
if calculate_area(5, 3) > 10:   # In conditions
  8. Function signature:
    • The first line of a function (def name(params):) is called the signature
    • It tells you what inputs the function needs
    • Number of arguments must match number of parameters

ğŸš€ Coming Up Next:

In the next lesson, you'll learn about variable scope - why variables inside functions are different from variables outside, and how Python decides which variable to use. Understanding scope prevents many common bugs!

checkpoint_quiz.question: What is the difference between a parameter and an argument?
options: There is no difference, they're the same thing
Parameters are in the function definition, arguments are values passed when calling
Parameters are for numbers, arguments are for strings
Arguments are in the function definition, parameters are when calling
checkpoint_quiz.explanation: Parameters are variables in the function DEFINITION (def greet(name):), while arguments are the actual VALUES you pass when CALLING the function (greet('Alice')). Think: parameters are empty boxes in the recipe, arguments are the ingredients you put in.

checkpoint_quiz.question:
What does this function return?

def calculate(x):
    result = x * 3
    print(result)

value = calculate(5)
checkpoint_quiz.explanation: This function returns None! It prints 15 to the screen, but there's no 'return' statement, so Python automatically returns None. The variable 'value' will be None, not 15. To fix this, add 'return result' at the end.

checkpoint_quiz.question: How do you return multiple values from a function?
options: Separate values with commas: return value1, value2
Put values in square brackets: return [value1, value2]
checkpoint_quiz.explanation: Use commas to return multiple values: 'return first, last'. Python automatically packs them into a tuple. You can then unpack when receiving: 'first_name, last_name = get_names()'. Option C (list) would work but returns a single list object, not multiple values.
